metadata.case_name: Bhuvan Mohan Patnaik & Ors. v. State of Andhra Pradesh & Ors.

facts.text: Bhuvan Mohan Patnaik, petitioner in Writ Petition No. 295 of 1974, is undergoing sentences of 4 1/2 years and 5 1/2 years awarded in two sessions cases and is an under-trial prisoner in the Parvatipuram Naxalite Conspiracy case.
Nagabhushan Patnaik, petitioner in Writ Petition No. 296 of 1974, was sentenced to death by the 11th Additional Sessions Judge, Visakhapatnam, commuted to life imprisonment by the State Government.
P. Hussainar, petitioner in Writ Petition No. 297 of 1974, is undergoing life imprisonment imposed by the same Judge and is an under-trial in the Parvatipuram Case.
All three petitioners are undergoing sentences in the Central Jail at Visakhapatnam.
Petitioners seek removal of armed police guards posted around the jail and dismantling of livewire electrical mechanism on top of the jail wall.

Superintendent of Central Jail, Visakhapatnam (3rd respondent) filed affidavit stating usual watch and ward staff inadequate, services of Andhra Pradesh Special Police Force requisitioned to guard jail from outside.
Policemen live in huts on vacant jail land appurtenant to prison; officers accommodated in jail club outside jail; office in block outside jail meant for visitors.
146 Naxalite prisoners lodged in Visakhapatnam jail, making usual arrangements inadequate.
Eleven Naxalite prisoners, including Nagabhushan Patnaik and P. Hussainar, escaped from prison on the night of October 8, 1969.

Livewire mechanism installed on top of wall 14 feet from ground (wall 13 feet high), rests on enamel non-conductors fixed to angle irons embedded in wall, no direct contact with wall, no leakage possibility, walls 20 feet from cells, regularly inspected by electrician, prisoners warned, non-electrical barbed-wire fences jail walls.

Petitioners allege segregation of Naxalite prisoners in quarantine, inhuman treatment, subhuman conditions, marathon hunger-strike, difficulties in amenities like carrom powder, defective radio and musical instruments.

3rd respondent claims airy rooms, cross-ventilation, 4000 calories food (breakfast + two meals), extra for ulcer patient (chicken, milk, eggs), reading material, games (Volleyball, Kabbadi, Badminton, Ring tennis), musical instruments, radio network.

legal_issues.text: Whether posting of armed police guards of Andhra Pradesh Special Police Force around the jail, including occupation of appurtenant land, violates fundamental rights of prisoners.
Whether installation of livewire electrical mechanism on top of jail walls violates Article 21 of the Constitution.
Whether conditions of detention in jail violate Article 21.

petitioner_arguments.text: Discipline of prison must have authority of law; iron curtain needed between prisoners and police to prevent influence and tyranny; police occupy part of prison (appurtenant land) causing interference with fundamental rights.
Livewire mechanism subjects escaping prisoner to death penalty without authority of law; violates policy in Section 224 IPC (max 2 years RI and fine); flagrant violation of Article 21.
Segregation, inhuman treatment, subhuman conditions violate right to life and personal liberty under Article 21.

respondent_arguments.text: Livewire mechanism reasonable restriction to prevent escape.
Amenities provided are adequate; denies subhuman conditions.

court_reasoning.text: Convicts not denuded of all fundamental rights by conviction; incarceration deprives freedoms like movement but not others like property; entitled to Article 21 protection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right to dictate guards to prevent escape; police outside high walls cause no interference.

court_reasoning.text: Infiltration of police into prisons deprecated, especially for under-trials, but here police have no access inside enclosed jail; hypothetical considerations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Presence in vicinity does not interfere with personal liberty.

court_reasoning.text: No satisfactory proof of subhuman conditions violating Article 21; matters of reform, extend Article 42 to jail conditions; barbarous punishments offend Constitution.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Allegations not proven; hope amenities true.

court_reasoning.text: Livewire lacks statutory basis (not law under Article 13(3)(a) or procedure under Article 21), but no violation of rights as contact only if attempt escape; no fundamental right to escape.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preventive deterrent; similar to high walls.

court_reasoning.text: Does not contravene CrPC Section 46(3); not causing death by itself, only if prisoner attempts escape.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Analogy to arrest/escape provisions inapplicable directly.

holdings.text: Posting of police guards outside jail on appurtenant land does not violate fundamental rights.
Livewire mechanism does not interfere with fundamental rights under Article 21.
No proven violation of Article 21 by jail conditions.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Prabhakar Pandurang Sangzgiri
precedents_cited.relevance: Detenu's right to send manuscript for publication; conditions of detention imply basic necessities; infringement of liberty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kharak Singh v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Approved US view on 'life' meaning more than animal existence.
'Life' includes faculties by which life enjoyed; due process.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ jurisdiction; right to life/liberty; law/procedure; humane conditions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishment for escape from custody (max 2 years RI, fine); contrasted with livewire.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Mode of arrest, force; no right to cause death except for serious offences; analogy to escape/retaking.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Rules, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions of detention imply basic rights.

outcome.summary: The writ petitions are dismissed as the acts complained of (police guards and livewire) do not interfere with fundamental rights; rule discharged.

key_quotes.text: Convicts are not, by mere reason of the conviction, denuded of all the fundamental rights which they otherwise possess.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms prisoners retain fundamental rights except those inherently lost by incarceration.

key_quotes.text: No person, not even a prisoner, can be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Whatever be the nature and extent of the petitioners' fundamental right to life and personal liberty, they have no fundamental freedom to escape from lawful custody.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on livewire; no right to escape.
